## Useful Expressions for Daily Life

## Belgian-Specific Vocabulary

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

**Before we dive into grammar, watch out for these common mistakes:**

**Mistake 1:** "J'habite dans Bruxelles" ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "J'habite √† Bruxelles" or "J'habite dans le quartier de..." ‚úÖ  
**Why:** For cities, use "√†" (J'habite √† Bruxelles). Use "dans" for specific neighborhoods or areas (J'habite dans le quartier de Ixelles).

**Mistake 2:** "O√π tu habites ?" in formal contexts ‚ùå

**Why:** In administrative contexts (commune, official forms), always use the formal "vous" form, not "tu".

**Use "√†" for:**

**Use "dans" for:**

## How to Ask "Where Do You Live?"

**Formal:**

- **Dans quel quartier habitez-vous ?** [d…ëÃÉ k…õl ka Åtje abit vu] = "Which neighborhood do you live in?"

**Informal:**

## How to Answer

**Simple answers:**
- **J'habite √† Bruxelles.** [ íabit a b Åyks…õl] = "I live in Brussels."
- **J'habite √† Ixelles.** [ íabit a iks…õl] = "I live in Ixelles."

**More detailed:**
- **J'habite dans le quartier de Saint-Gilles.** [ íabit d…ëÃÉ l…ô ka Åtje d…ô s…õÃÉ  íil] = "I live in the Saint-Gilles neighborhood."
- **J'habite √† Bruxelles, dans le quartier d'Ixelles.** [ íabit a b Åyks…õl d…ëÃÉ l…ô ka Åtje diks…õl] = "I live in Brussels, in the Ixelles neighborhood."

**üí° Note:** "d'Ixelles" = "de Ixelles" (the "de" becomes "d'" before a vowel!)

---

## Grammar Exercises: Let's Practice!

## Exercise 1: Complete with "√†" or "dans" (Part 1 - Basic)

**Fill in the blanks with "√†" or "dans"!**

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

**Before we dive into grammar, watch out for these common mistakes:**

**Mistake 1:** Confusing "r√©gion" (region) and "pays" (country) ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "La Belgique est un pays avec trois r√©gions" ‚úÖ  
**Why:** Belgium is the "pays" (country), Flanders/Wallonia/Brussels are "r√©gions" (regions). Know the difference!

**Mistake 2:** Saying "Bruxelles parle fran√ßais" (wrong verb) ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "√Ä Bruxelles, on parle fran√ßais et n√©erlandais" or "Bruxelles est bilingue" ‚úÖ  
**Why:** Cities don't "speak" - people do. Use "on parle" (people speak) or describe the city as bilingual.

**Mistake 3:** Capitalizing regions incorrectly ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "la Flandre", "la Wallonie", "Bruxelles-Capitale" ‚úÖ  
**Why:** In French, regions are capitalized when they're proper nouns. "La Flandre" (the region), but check if it's part of a sentence.

**Mistake 4:** Confusing "bilingue" (bilingual) and "multilingue" (multilingual) ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "Bruxelles est bilingue" (2 languages: French and Dutch) ‚úÖ  
**Why:** "Bilingue" = 2 languages, "multilingue" = many languages. Brussels is officially bilingual (French/Dutch), but multilingual in practice due to expats.

**When talking about regions in Belgium:**

## Let's Start! Your Calendar Adventure!

## üìã Introduction

**Did you guess A (Monday)?** üéâ **You're absolutely right!**

**"Lundi"** [l≈ìÃÉdi] means **"Monday"** in English!

Welcome to your lesson about days of the week and months! üéâ

Knowing days and months is essential for daily life in Belgium! You'll need them to make appointments, plan meetings, talk about events, and understand schedules!

**What you will learn today:**
- All 7 days of the week in French
- All 12 months in French
- How to say dates
- How to talk about when things happen

**Why this matters in Belgium:**
When you make appointments at the commune, doctor's office, or with friends, you'll need to know days and months! Plus, understanding Belgian holidays and events requires knowing the calendar! üí™

---

## üéÆ Warm-up Activity: Day Match!

**Let's play a matching game!** üéÆ

You're looking at a French calendar. Can you match each French day with its English meaning?

**Match these days:**

1. **lundi** [l≈ìÃÉdi]

3. **mercredi** [m…õ Åk Å…ôdi]
   - A) Wednesday
   - B) Thursday

4. **jeudi** [ í√∏di]

5. **vendredi** [v…ëÃÉd Å…ôdi]

**Write down your answers: 1-?, 2-?, 3-?, 4-?, 5-?**

**Ready to check?**
- **1-A (Monday)** ‚úÖ - "Lundi" = Monday
- **2-B (Tuesday)** ‚úÖ - "Mardi" = Tuesday
- **3-A (Wednesday)** ‚úÖ - "Mercredi" = Wednesday

---

## French Pronunciation: Quick Reference

**üìö Remember:** For complete pronunciation help, check out `Prononciation/00_Decouvrir_la_Prononciation_Francaise.md`!

**Key sounds in today's words:**
- **lundi** [l≈ìÃÉdi] - Notice the nasal sound [≈ìÃÉ]!
- **mardi** [ma Ådi] - French R [ Å]!
- **janvier** [ í…ëÃÉvje] - Nasal […ëÃÉ]!
- **d√©cembre** [des…ëÃÉb Å] - Nasal […ëÃÉ] and French R [ Å]!

**üí° Practice tip:** All days and months have IPA transcriptions [in brackets]. Use them to practice!

---

## Vocabulary: Essential Words

## Days of the Week

**Here are all 7 days of the week in French!** Each one has its pronunciation in IPA! üé§

| Fran√ßais | IPA | English | Note |
|----------|-----|---------|------|
| **lundi** | [l≈ìÃÉdi] | Monday | First day of the week |
| **mardi** | [ma Ådi] | Tuesday | |
| **mercredi** | [m…õ Åk Å…ôdi] | Wednesday | |
| **jeudi** | [ í√∏di] | Thursday | |
| **vendredi** | [v…ëÃÉd Å…ôdi] | Friday | |
| **samedi** | [samdi] | Saturday | |
| **dimanche** | [dim…ëÃÉ É] | Sunday | Day of rest |

**üí° Important notes:**
- Days of the week are **NOT capitalized** in French! (lundi, not Lundi)
- Days are **masculine** - use "le" (le lundi = on Monday)
- The week starts on Monday in France/Belgium (not Sunday like in some countries)

**üéØ Try it!** Can you say all 7 days in order?

**üé§ Pronunciation practice:** Say each day 3 times with correct pronunciation! Focus on those nasal sounds!

## Months of the Year

**Here are all 12 months in French!** Each one has its pronunciation in IPA! üé§

| Fran√ßais | IPA | English | Note |
|----------|-----|---------|------|
| **janvier** | [ í…ëÃÉvje] | January | First month |
| **f√©vrier** | [fev Åije] | February | |
| **mars** | [ma Ås] | March | |
| **avril** | [av Åil] | April | |
| **mai** | [m…õ] | May | |
| **juin** | [ í…•…õÃÉ] | June | |
| **juillet** | [ í…•ij…õ] | July | |
| **ao√ªt** | [u] | August | |
| **septembre** | [s…õpt…ëÃÉb Å] | September | |

| **novembre** | [n…îv…ëÃÉb Å] | November | |

**üí° Important notes:**
- Months are **NOT capitalized** in French! (janvier, not Janvier)
- Months are **masculine** - use "le" (le janvier = in January)
- "Ao√ªt" [u] is pronounced like "ou" (sounds like "oo")

**üé§ Pronunciation practice:** Say each month 3 times with correct pronunciation!

## Useful Expressions for Daily Life

**These expressions will help you talk about dates and time!** üé§

- **Quel jour sommes-nous ?** [k…õl  íu Å s…îm nu] : What day is it?
- **Nous sommes lundi.** [nu s…îm l≈ìÃÉdi] : It's Monday.
- **Quelle est la date aujourd'hui ?** [k…õl …õ la dat o íu Åd…•i] : What's the date today?
- **Aujourd'hui, c'est le 15 mars.** [o íu Åd…•i s…õ l…ô k…õÃÉz ma Ås] : Today is March 15th.
- **Quand ?** [k…ëÃÉ] : When?
- **Lundi prochain** [l≈ìÃÉdi p Å…î É…õÃÉ] : Next Monday
- **Lundi dernier** [l≈ìÃÉdi d…õ Ånje] : Last Monday
- **Le week-end** [l…ô wik…õnd] : The weekend (used in French too!)
- **En janvier** […ëÃÉ  í…ëÃÉvje] : In January

**üí° Pronunciation note:** Notice "sommes-nous" [s…îm nu] - the "s" in "sommes" connects with "nous" (liaison)!

## Belgian-Specific Vocabulary

**These expressions are useful for talking about dates in Belgium!** üáßüá™

- **Les jours f√©ri√©s** [le  íu Å fe Åje] : Public holidays

**üé§ Pronunciation challenge:** Try saying "jours f√©ri√©s" [ íu Å fe Åje] - practice 5 times!

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

**Before we dive into grammar, watch out for these common mistakes:**

**Mistake 1:** Capitalizing days and months ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "lundi" (not "Lundi"), "janvier" (not "Janvier") ‚úÖ  
**Why:** In French, days of the week and months are NOT capitalized (unlike English). Only capitalize them if they're at the start of a sentence.

**Mistake 2:** "C'est 15 mars" (missing "le") ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "C'est le 15 mars" ‚úÖ

**Mistake 3:** "Nous sommes en lundi" (wrong preposition) ‚ùå

**Mistake 4:** Confusing "en janvier" and "le janvier" ‚ùå

## Grammar: Talking About Dates

## Exercise 3: Create Sentences About Dates (Part 3 - Real Situations!)

3. A day you like: J'aime _______________. (I like [day])
4. A month you like: J'aime _______________. (I like [month])
5. Next week: La semaine prochaine, c'est _______________. (Next week is...)

**Example:**
- Aujourd'hui, c'est le 15 mars.
- Mon anniversaire est le 20 juin.
- J'aime samedi.
- J'aime mai.
- La semaine prochaine, c'est la semaine du 22 mars.

**üí° Tip:** Use real dates if you can!

## Writing Exercise 2: Complete Schedule

**Write a short paragraph (5-7 sentences) about your week!**

Include:
- What day it is today
- What you do on different days
- Your favorite day
- Plans for the weekend
- One sentence about a month you like

**Example:**
> Aujourd'hui, c'est lundi le 15 mars. Le lundi, je travaille. Le mardi, je vais au march√©. J'aime le samedi parce que c'est le week-end. Ce samedi, je vais visiter Bruxelles. J'aime le mois de mai parce que c'est le printemps.

**üí° Don't worry about:** Perfect grammar, complex sentences, or using words you don't know yet!

**‚úÖ Focus on:** Using the vocabulary you learned today, writing complete sentences, and expressing yourself!

**üéâ Excellent writing!** You're creating real French texts about dates!

---

## Exercices Suppl√©mentaires (Additional Exercises)

**üí° Note:** These exercises are optional! Do them only if you want extra practice. The exercises above are enough to master the lesson content.

## Exercise 4: More Day Practice

**Complete the sentences:**

1. Apr√®s lundi, c'est _______________.
2. Avant jeudi, c'est _______________.
3. Le week-end, c'est _______________ et _______________.
4. Le premier jour de la semaine, c'est _______________.
5. Le dernier jour de la semaine, c'est _______________.

**Answers:**
1. ‚úÖ mardi
2. ‚úÖ mercredi
3. ‚úÖ samedi, dimanche

## Exercise 5: More Month Practice

**Answer these questions:**

1. Quel mois vient apr√®s janvier ? _______________
2. Quel mois vient avant mars ? _______________

**Answers:**

2. ‚úÖ f√©vrier

## Exercise 6: Create More Date Sentences

**Write 5 sentences using dates:**

1. A sentence with "lundi": _______________

**Example answers:**

---

## Real-World Practice: Try This Today!

**This week, challenge yourself to use what you've learned:**

**Practice opportunities:**
- [ ] Every day, practice saying today's date in French: "C'est le [number] [month]"
- [ ] When making appointments, practice saying the day in French
- [ ] Mark important dates on your calendar and practice reading them in French
- [ ] Practice saying days of the week when planning your week

**Don't worry if days and months are tricky at first - practice makes perfect!**  
**The most important thing is to practice daily - say the date in French every morning!**

**Success tip:** Change your phone/computer calendar to French (if possible) to see days and months in French daily!

---

## Troubleshooting: Having Trouble?

**If you're struggling with days of the week:**
- Practice saying all 7 days in order: lundi, mardi, mercredi, jeudi, vendredi, samedi, dimanche
- Repeat them 10 times every day until they're automatic
- Practice saying "Aujourd'hui, c'est [day]" (Today is [day]) daily
- Use a French calendar or app to see days in French

**If months are overwhelming:**
- Learn 4 at a time: janvier, f√©vrier, mars, avril (practice these), then mai, juin, juillet, ao√ªt, etc.
- Practice saying your birth month and important months for you
- Practice the pattern: "C'est le [number] [month]"
- Don't try to memorize all 12 months perfectly at once - build gradually

**If dates are confusing:**
- Remember: Always use "le" before dates: "C'est le 15 mars"
- Remember: 1st = "1er" (premier), others = regular numbers (2, 3, 4...)
- Practice pattern: "C'est le [number] [month]" - say it 20 times
- Practice with real dates: your birthday, today's date, upcoming appointments

**If prepositions confuse you:**
- Simple rule: "en" for months (en janvier), no preposition for days (lundi, not "en lundi")
- Practice: "Je vais en janvier" (I'm going in January), "Je vais lundi" (I'm going Monday)
- Focus on YOUR most common uses first

**Still stuck?** Days and months take time. Focus on today's day and date first, then gradually add more. Practice daily - even 2 minutes saying the date in French helps!

---

## Culture: Belgian Calendar and Holidays

## Did You Know?

**Belgium has many public holidays!** üáßüá™

**Important dates:**
- **January 1st** - New Year's Day (Jour de l'An)
- **Easter Monday** (Lundi de P√¢ques) - Date changes each year
- **May 1st** - Labor Day (F√™te du Travail)
- **Ascension Day** (Ascension) - 40 days after Easter
- **Whit Monday** (Lundi de Pentec√¥te) - 50 days after Easter
- **July 21st** - National Day (F√™te nationale) üáßüá™
- **August 15th** - Assumption (Assomption)
- **November 1st** - All Saints' Day (Toussaint)
- **November 11th** - Armistice Day (Armistice)
- **December 25th** - Christmas (No√´l)

**Belgian traditions:**
- **Christmas markets** - Start in December, very popular!
- **National Day** - Big celebration in Brussels on July 21st!
- **Carnival** - Celebrated in some cities (like Binche) in February/March

## Tips for Expats

**When talking about dates in Belgium:**

1. **Remember the format** - Day comes before month (15 mars, not March 15)
2. **Use "le" before dates** - "C'est le 15 mars" not "C'est 15 mars"
3. **Days are not capitalized** - "lundi" not "Lundi"
4. **Months are not capitalized** - "mars" not "Mars"
5. **Week starts on Monday** - Not Sunday like in some countries

**Comparaison culturelle / Cultural comparison:**

**Dans beaucoup de pays (UK, US, etc.) :** 
- Format de date : mois/jour (March 15, 03/15)
- La semaine commence le dimanche
- Les jours sont capitalis√©s (Monday)

**En Belgique :**
- Format de date : jour/mois (15 mars, 15/03)
- La semaine commence le lundi
- Les jours ne sont PAS capitalis√©s (lundi)
- On utilise "le" avant les dates : "C'est le 15 mars"

**Pourquoi c'est important :** Comprendre le format belge √©vite les confusions dans les rendez-vous et les documents administratifs !

**Useful phrases:**
- **Quand ?** [k…ëÃÉ] = When?
- **Quel jour ?** [k…õl  íu Å] = What day?
- **Quelle date ?** [k…õl dat] = What date?
- **C'est quand ?** [s…õ k…ëÃÉ] = When is it?

**üí° Pro tip:** Mark Belgian holidays on your calendar! Many shops and offices are closed on public holidays!

---

## Wrap-up: What You've Learned Today

**Congratulations!** üéâ You've completed another lesson!

**Here's what you can now do:**

‚úÖ **Name all 7 days** of the week in French  
‚úÖ **Name all 12 months** in French  
‚úÖ **Say what day it is** using "Nous sommes..."  
‚úÖ **Say dates** using "C'est le [number] [month]"  
‚úÖ **Make plans** using days and dates

**Key vocabulary you learned:**
- Days: lundi, mardi, mercredi, jeudi, vendredi, samedi, dimanche
- Months: janvier, f√©vrier, mars, avril, mai, juin, juillet, ao√ªt, septembre, octobre, novembre, d√©cembre
- Expressions: "Quel jour sommes-nous ?", "Quelle est la date ?", "On se voit [day]?"





**What to practice:**
- Say all days and months out loud 5 times each!
- Write 10 dates in French
- Practice asking and answering about dates
- Review the prepositions "le", "en", "au mois de"

**Next lesson preview:** You'll learn how to express likes and dislikes (j'aime, je n'aime pas)! ‚ù§Ô∏è

**Remember:** Every time you check the date, try saying it in French! Practice makes perfect! üí™

---

## Self-Check: Can You...?

- **Date Check:** Every morning, say the correct date aloud ("Aujourd'hui, c'est lundi 15...").
- **Planner:** Write your appointments for next week in French (e.g., "Mardi: Dentiste").

*Bonne continuation dans votre apprentissage du fran√ßais en Belgique !*

# Le√ßon 10 : Parler de ses go√ªts (j'aime, je n'aime pas)

**Niveau** : A1.1  
**Dur√©e estim√©e** : 2-3 heures  
**Objectifs** : Apprendre √† exprimer ses go√ªts et d√©go√ªts, parler de ce qu'on aime

---


## Let's Start! Your Preferences Adventure!

## üé≤ Discovery Activity: What Do They Like?

**Here's a fun situation!** üéÆ

You're at a caf√© in Brussels with a new friend. They say:

"J'**aime** le chocolat belge ! Et toi ?" (I like Belgian chocolate! And you?)

**Your challenge:** Can you guess what "j'aime" means?

**Match the expression with its meaning:**

**A)** I like  
**B)** I don't like  
**C)** I want  

**Write down your guess:**
- j'aime = ?

*(Hint: Think about the word "aimer" - it might sound like "amour" which means "love"!)*

**Don't worry if you're not sure - we'll discover the answers together!** ü§î

**Ready to learn about likes and dislikes?** Keep reading! üëá

---

## üìã Introduction

**Did you guess A (I like)?** üéâ **You're absolutely right!**

**"J'aime"** [ í…õm] means **"I like"** in English!

Welcome to your lesson about expressing likes and dislikes! üéâ

Being able to say what you like and don't like is super important for conversations! Whether you're talking about food, activities, music, or anything else, this lesson will help you express yourself!

**What you will learn today:**
- How to say "I like" (j'aime) and "I don't like" (je n'aime pas)
- The verb "aimer" (to like/love)
- Vocabulary for common things people like/dislike
- How to ask "Do you like...?"
- Expressions for preferences

**Why this matters in Belgium:**
When you're at a restaurant, talking about hobbies, or making friends, you'll want to express your preferences! Belgians love talking about food, beer, and activities - this lesson will help you join the conversation! üí™

---

## üéÆ Warm-up Activity: Like or Dislike?

**Let's play a matching game!** üéÆ

You're learning to express preferences. Can you match each French expression with its English meaning?

**Match these expressions:**

1. **J'aime** [ í…õm]
   - A) I like
   - B) I don't like
   - C) I want

2. **Je n'aime pas** [ í…ô n…õm pa]
   - A) I like
   - B) I don't like
   - C) I love

3. **J'adore** [ íad…î Å]
   - A) I like
   - B) I love
   - C) I hate

4. **Je d√©teste** [ í…ô det…õst]
   - A) I like
   - B) I don't like
   - C) I hate

5. **Tu aimes ?** [ty …õm]
   - A) Do you like?
   - B) Do you want?
   - C) Do you have?

**Write down your answers: 1-?, 2-?, 3-?, 4-?, 5-?**

**Ready to check?**
- **1-A (I like)** ‚úÖ - "J'aime" = I like
- **2-B (I don't like)** ‚úÖ - "Je n'aime pas" = I don't like
- **3-B (I love)** ‚úÖ - "J'adore" = I love (stronger than "j'aime")
- **4-C (I hate)** ‚úÖ - "Je d√©teste" = I hate
- **5-A (Do you like?)** ‚úÖ - "Tu aimes ?" = Do you like?

**üéâ How many did you get right?** You're learning preferences! üôå

---

## French Pronunciation: Quick Reference

**üìö Remember:** For complete pronunciation help, check out `Prononciation/00_Decouvrir_la_Prononciation_Francaise.md`!

**Key sounds in today's words:**
- **j'aime** [ í…õm] - Notice the soft "j" [ í] sound!
- **chocolat** [ É…îk…îla] - The "ch" sounds like "sh" [ É]!
- **aime** […õm] - The "ai" makes the […õ] sound (like "e" in "bed")!

**üí° Practice tip:** All expressions have IPA transcriptions [in brackets]. Use them to practice!

---

## Vocabulary: Essential Words

## Expressing Likes and Dislikes

**Here are ways to express preferences in French!** Each one has its pronunciation in IPA! üé§

| Fran√ßais | IPA | English | Intensity |
|----------|-----|---------|-----------|
| **J'aime** | [ í…õm] | I like | Neutral |
| **J'aime beaucoup** | [ í…õm boku] | I like a lot | Strong |
| **J'adore** | [ íad…î Å] | I love | Very strong |
| **Je n'aime pas** | [ í…ô n…õm pa] | I don't like | Negative |
| **Je n'aime pas du tout** | [ í…ô n…õm pa dy tu] | I don't like at all | Very negative |
| **Je d√©teste** | [ í…ô det…õst] | I hate | Very negative |

**üí° Important notes:**
- "Aimer" can mean "to like" or "to love" depending on context
- "Adorer" is stronger than "aimer" (I love vs I like)
- "D√©tester" is very strong (I hate)

**üéØ Try it!** Can you say what you like and don't like?

**üé§ Pronunciation practice:** Say each expression 3 times with correct pronunciation!

## Common Things People Like/Dislike

**Here are common things to talk about!** üé§

**Food (La nourriture):**
- **le chocolat** [l…ô  É…îk…îla] : chocolate
- **les frites** [le f Åit] : fries (Belgian specialty!)
- **la bi√®re** [la bj…õ Å] : beer
- **le caf√©** [l…ô kafe] : coffee
- **le fromage** [l…ô f Å…îma í] : cheese
- **les gaufres** [le gof Å] : waffles

**Activities (Les activit√©s):**
- **lire** [li Å] : to read
- **√©couter de la musique** [ekute d…ô la myzik] : to listen to music
- **regarder des films** [ Å…ôga Åde de film] : to watch movies
- **faire du sport** [f…õ Å dy sp…î Å] : to do sports
- **voyager** [vwaja íe] : to travel
- **cuisiner** [k…•izine] : to cook

**Places (Les lieux):**
- **Bruxelles** [b Åyks…õl] : Brussels
- **les mus√©es** [le myze] : museums
- **les parcs** [le pa Åk] : parks
- **les restaurants** [le  Å…õst…î Å…ëÃÉ] : restaurants

**üí° Fun fact:** Belgians LOVE frites (fries)! They're a national treasure! üáßüá™

**üé§ Pronunciation practice:** Say each word 3 times!

## Useful Expressions for Daily Life

**These expressions will help you talk about preferences!** üé§

- **Qu'est-ce que tu aimes ?** [k…õs k…ô ty …õm] : What do you like? (informal)
- **Qu'est-ce que vous aimez ?** [k…õs k…ô vu …õme] : What do you like? (formal)
- **Tu aimes... ?** [ty …õm] : Do you like...? (informal)
- **Vous aimez... ?** [vu …õme] : Do you like...? (formal)
- **Moi aussi !** [mwa osi] : Me too!
- **Moi non plus.** [mwa n…îÃÉ ply] : Me neither.
- **Moi, j'aime...** [mwa  í…õm] : I like... (emphasizing "I")
- **Et toi ?** [e twa] : And you? (informal)
- **Et vous ?** [e vu] : And you? (formal)

**üéØ Practice Challenge:** Create a mini-conversation! Write 4 lines about preferences.

**Example:**
- **A:** Tu aimes le chocolat ?
- **B:** Oui, j'adore le chocolat ! Et toi ?
- **A:** Moi aussi ! J'aime beaucoup le chocolat belge.
- **B:** C'est d√©licieux !

**üí° Pronunciation note:** Notice "aimez" […õme] - the "z" is silent but the "e" is pronounced!

## Belgian-Specific Vocabulary

**These are things Belgians love to talk about!** üáßüá™

- **Les frites** [le f Åit] : Fries (Belgian specialty - they're the best!)
- **Les gaufres** [le gof Å] : Waffles (Brussels or Li√®ge style!)
- **Le chocolat belge** [l…ô  É…îk…îla b…õl í] : Belgian chocolate
- **La bi√®re belge** [la bj…õ Å b…õl í] : Belgian beer
- **Les moules-frites** [le mul f Åit] : Mussels and fries (classic Belgian dish!)

**Fun fact:** Belgium has over 1000 types of beer! And Belgian chocolate is world-famous! üç´üç∫

**üé§ Pronunciation challenge:** Try saying "moules-frites" [mul f Åit] - practice 5 times!

---

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

**Before we dive into grammar, watch out for these common mistakes:**

**Mistake 1:** "J'aime le chocolat" vs "J'aime chocolat" (missing article) ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "J'aime le chocolat" (with article) ‚úÖ  
**Why:** In French, you need the article "le/la/les" when talking about things in general. "J'aime le chocolat" (I like chocolate in general).

**Mistake 2:** "Je n'aime pas le chocolat" - forgetting "pas" ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "Je n'aime pas le chocolat" ‚úÖ  
**Why:** To make "aimer" negative, you need both "ne" and "pas": "Je n'aime pas" (I don't like). Don't forget "pas"!

**Mistake 3:** Confusing "j'aime" (I like) and "j'aime bien" (I quite like) ‚ùå  
**Correct:** Both are correct, but "j'aime bien" is softer than "j'aime" ‚úÖ  
**Why:** "J'aime" = I like, "J'aime bien" = I quite like (softer). "J'aime" is stronger, "j'aime bien" is more neutral.

**Mistake 4:** "Je aime" (two words) ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "J'aime" (one word with apostrophe) ‚úÖ  
**Why:** Before a vowel, "je" becomes "j'" with an apostrophe. Always write "J'aime" not "Je aime".

**Mistake 5:** Using "aimer" with infinitives incorrectly: "J'aime √† manger" ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "J'aime manger" (direct infinitive) ‚úÖ  
**Why:** "Aimer" is followed directly by the infinitive: "J'aime manger" (I like to eat), not "J'aime √† manger".

---

## Grammar: The Verb "Aimer" (To Like/Love)

## How to Conjugate "Aimer"

**This is how you say "to like" or "to love" in French!** It's a regular -er verb!

**How to form it:**

| Pronom | Verbe "aimer" | English | IPA |
|--------|---------------|---------|-----|
| J' | aime | I like | [ í…õm] |
| Tu | aimes | You like (informal) | [ty …õm] |
| Il/Elle | aime | He/She likes | [il/…õl …õm] |
| Nous | aimons | We like | [nuz …õm…îÃÉ] |
| Vous | aimez | You like (formal/plural) | [vu …õme] |
| Ils/Elles | aiment | They like | [il/…õl …õm] |

**üí° Important:** "J'aime" uses an apostrophe because "je" + vowel sound = "j'"

**Examples you'll actually use:**
- **J'aime le chocolat.** [ í…õm l…ô  É…îk…îla] = "I like chocolate."
- **Tu aimes Bruxelles ?** [ty …õm b Åyks…õl] = "Do you like Brussels?"
- **Elle aime les mus√©es.** […õl …õm le myze] = "She likes museums."
- **Nous aimons voyager.** [nuz …õm…îÃÉ vwaja íe] = "We like to travel."

**üí° Memory trick:** "Aimer" sounds a bit like "aim" in English - think "I aim to like it" = "J'aime"!

**üé§ Pronunciation practice:** Say "J'aime" [ í…õm] 10 times! Notice the soft "j" [ í] sound!

## How to Say "I Don't Like"

**Use "ne... pas" around the verb:**

- **Je n'aime pas** [ í…ô n…õm pa] = "I don't like"
- **Je n'aime pas le caf√©.** [ í…ô n…õm pa l…ô kafe] = "I don't like coffee."
- **Tu n'aimes pas ?** [ty n…õm pa] = "Don't you like?"

**üí° Note:** "Ne" becomes "n'" before a vowel: "Je n'aime pas" not "Je ne aime pas"

## Using "Aimer" with Different Things

**With nouns (use "le/la/les"):**
- **J'aime le chocolat.** [ í…õm l…ô  É…îk…îla] = "I like chocolate."
- **J'aime la bi√®re.** [ í…õm la bj…õ Å] = "I like beer."
- **J'aime les frites.** [ í…õm le f Åit] = "I like fries."

**With verbs (use infinitive):**
- **J'aime lire.** [ í…õm li Å] = "I like to read."
- **J'aime voyager.** [ í…õm vwaja íe] = "I like to travel."
- **J'aime faire du sport.** [ í…õm f…õ Å dy sp…î Å] = "I like to do sports."

**üí° Memory trick:** Think "I like TO read" = "J'aime lire" (no "to" in French, just the infinitive!)

---

## Grammar Exercises: Let's Practice!

## Exercise 1: Conjugate "Aimer" (Part 1 - Basic)

**Complete the sentences with the correct form of "aimer":**

1. Je _______________ le chocolat. (I like chocolate)
2. Tu _______________ Bruxelles ? (Do you like Brussels?)
3. Elle _______________ les mus√©es. (She likes museums)
4. Nous _______________ voyager. (We like to travel)
5. Vous _______________ la bi√®re ? (Do you like beer?)

**Write your answers:**
1. _______________
2. _______________
3. _______________
4. _______________
5. _______________

**Check your answers:**
1. ‚úÖ aime […õm]
2. ‚úÖ aimes […õm]
3. ‚úÖ aime […õm]
4. ‚úÖ aimons […õm…îÃÉ]
5. ‚úÖ aimez […õme]

**üéâ Great job!** You're conjugating "aimer"!

## Exercise 2: Express Preferences (Part 2 - More Practice!)

**Complete the sentences:**

1. J'_______________ le chocolat belge. (I like Belgian chocolate)
2. Je n'_______________ pas le caf√©. (I don't like coffee)
3. Tu _______________ les frites ? (Do you like fries?)
4. Nous _______________ Bruxelles. (We like Brussels)
5. Ils _______________ voyager. (They like to travel)

**Check your answers:**
1. ‚úÖ aime
2. ‚úÖ aime
3. ‚úÖ aimes
4. ‚úÖ aimons
5. ‚úÖ aiment

**üí° Tip:** Remember "j'aime" uses an apostrophe!

## Exercise 3: Create Sentences About Preferences (Part 3 - Real Situations!)

**Create complete sentences in French!**

**Situation 1:** Someone asks what you like.

**Write your answer:**
- **Question:** Qu'est-ce que tu aimes ?
- **Your answer:** J'aime _______________. (Say 3 things you like!)

**Situation 2:** You're talking about food preferences.

**Write 3 sentences:**

## Survival Phrases: When You Don't Understand

## Speaking Practice: Your Turn!

## Solo Speaking Practice (If you're studying alone)

## Dialogue Model: Talking About Preferences

**Tips for practicing:**

## Speaking: Role Play - Talking About Preferences

## Your Turn to Speak!

## Writing: Your Preferences

## Writing Exercise 1: Simple Preferences

## Writing Exercise 2: Complete Description

## Exercices Suppl√©mentaires (Additional Exercises)

## Exercise 4: More "Aimer" Conjugation

**This week, challenge yourself to use what you've learned:**

## Troubleshooting: Having Trouble?

**If you're struggling with "aimer" conjugation:**
- Write out the conjugation 5 times: j'aime, tu aimes, il/elle aime, nous aimons, vous aimez, ils/elles aiment
- Practice "J'aime" 20 times - make it automatic
- Remember: "J'aime" (I like), "Tu aimes" (You like), "Il/Elle aime" (He/She likes)
- Pay attention to the endings: -e, -es, -e, -ons, -ez, -ent

**If negative sentences confuse you:**
- Remember: "Je n'aime pas" needs both "ne" and "pas"
- Practice pattern: "Je n'aime pas [thing]" - repeat it 20 times
- Common mistake: forgetting "pas" - always include it!
- Practice: "J'aime le chocolat" ‚Üí "Je n'aime pas le chocolat"

**If using articles with "aimer" is confusing:**
- Remember: "J'aime le chocolat" (I like chocolate in general)
- Practice: "J'aime le/la/les [thing]" - always use the article
- Exception: with infinitives, no article: "J'aime manger" (not "J'aime le manger")

**If "j'aime" vs "j'adore" confuses you:**
- "J'aime" = I like (normal preference)
- "J'adore" = I love (stronger preference)
- "Je n'aime pas" = I don't like (negative)
- "Je d√©teste" = I hate (very negative)
- Start with "J'aime" and "Je n'aime pas" - add others gradually

**Still stuck?** "Aimer" is a very common verb. Focus on mastering "J'aime" and "Je n'aime pas" first. Practice daily with things you actually like/dislike - it helps!

---

## Culture: Belgian Food Culture

## Did You Know?

**Belgians are very proud of their food!** üáßüá™

**Belgian specialties:**
- **Frites (Fries)** - Invented in Belgium! Eaten with mayonnaise, not ketchup!
- **Gaufres (Waffles)** - Two types: Brussels style (rectangular, light) and Li√®ge style (round, thick)
- **Chocolat (Chocolate)** - World-famous! Brands like Neuhaus, Godiva, Leonidas
- **Bi√®re (Beer)** - Over 1000 types! Trappist beers, lambics, etc.
- **Moules-frites** - Mussels and fries, a classic Belgian dish

**Food culture:**
- Belgians take food seriously - meals are important social events
- Lunch break is usually 1 hour (12 PM - 1 PM)
- Many people go home for lunch (especially in smaller cities)
- Dinner is usually around 7-8 PM

**Comparaison culturelle / Cultural comparison:**

**Dans beaucoup de pays :**
- Les frites se mangent avec du ketchup
- Les repas sont souvent rapides
- On peut refuser poliment de la nourriture

**En Belgique :**
- Les frites se mangent avec de la mayonnaise (c'est la tradition !)
- Les repas sont des moments sociaux importants
- Refuser de la nourriture peut √™tre mal vu (essayez au moins un peu !)
- La gastronomie est tr√®s importante - les Belges en sont fiers

**Pourquoi c'est important :** Respecter les traditions culinaires belges montre votre int√©r√™t pour la culture locale et facilite l'int√©gration !

**Tips for expats:**
- Try Belgian specialties! They're delicious!
- Don't ask for ketchup with frites - use mayonnaise!
- Belgian chocolate makes great gifts
- Each beer has its own glass - respect the tradition!

**Useful phrases:**
- **C'est d√©licieux !** [s…õ delisj√∏] = It's delicious!
- **J'adore !** [ íad…î Å] = I love it!
- **C'est bon !** [s…õ b…îÃÉ] = It's good!
- **Je recommande** [ í…ô  Å…ôk…îm…ëÃÉd] = I recommend

**üí° Pro tip:** Visit a Belgian chocolate shop (chocolaterie) and try different types! It's an experience!

---

## Wrap-up: What You've Learned Today

**Congratulations!** üéâ You've completed another lesson!

**Here's what you can now do:**

‚úÖ **Express likes** using "J'aime..."  
‚úÖ **Express dislikes** using "Je n'aime pas..."  
‚úÖ **Say "I love"** using "J'adore..."  
‚úÖ **Ask about preferences** using "Tu aimes...?"  
‚úÖ **Conjugate the verb "aimer"** for all pronouns  
‚úÖ **Talk about food, activities, and places** you like  

**Key vocabulary you learned:**
- Expressions: j'aime, j'adore, je n'aime pas, je d√©teste
- Food: chocolat, frites, gaufres, bi√®re, caf√©, fromage
- Activities: lire, √©couter de la musique, voyager, faire du sport
- Responses: moi aussi, moi non plus, et toi ?





**What to practice:**
- Say all preference expressions out loud 5 times each!
- Write 10 sentences about what you like and don't like

- Review the verb "aimer" conjugation

**Next lesson preview:** You'll learn about colors and descriptions! üé®

**Remember:** Every conversation about preferences is practice! Don't be shy - share what you like! üí™

---

**Before moving on, check if you can:**

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

**Before we dive into grammar, watch out for these common mistakes:**

**Mistake 1:** Forgetting gender agreement with colors: "Une voiture rouge" (correct) vs "Une voiture rouge" if masculine ‚ùå  
**Correct:** Colors agree with the noun: "Une voiture rouge" (feminine), "Un livre rouge" (masculine) ‚úÖ  
**Why:** Most colors agree with gender. "Rouge" stays the same for both, but some change: "blanc/blanche", "vert/verte", etc.

**Mistake 2:** Capitalizing colors ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "rouge", "bleu", "vert" (not "Rouge", "Bleu") ‚úÖ  
**Why:** Colors are NOT capitalized in French (unlike in some languages). Only capitalize at the start of a sentence.

**Mistake 3:** "C'est une voiture rouge" vs "Elle est rouge" confusion ‚ùå  
**Correct:** Both work, but "C'est une voiture rouge" (It's a red car) or "Elle est rouge" (It is red) ‚úÖ  
**Why:** You can describe with "C'est [noun] [color]" or "Il/Elle est [color]". Both are correct, but structure is different.

**Mistake 4:** Using "de" before colors: "Une voiture de rouge" ‚ùå  
**Correct:** "Une voiture rouge" (no preposition) ‚úÖ  
**Why:** Colors come directly after the noun, no preposition needed. "Une voiture rouge" not "Une voiture de rouge".

# Le√ßon 12 : Se d√©placer √† Bruxelles

**Niveau** : A1.1  
**Dur√©e estim√©e** : 2-3 heures  
**Objectifs** : Apprendre √† utiliser les transports en commun, demander son chemin, utiliser les verbes aller, prendre et faire

---

## Let's Start! Getting Around Brussels

### Discovery Activity: Understanding Directions

**Here's a real situation you'll face:**

You just arrived in Brussels and you need to get to work. A colleague tells you:

**"Pour aller au bureau, tu prends le m√©tro √† la station Louise, tu fais la ligne 2 direction Elisabeth, et tu descends √† Arts-Loi."**

**Your challenge:** Look at these verbs and try to guess what they mean:

- **aller** - What do you think this means?
- **prendre** - What do you think this means?
- **faire** - What do you think this means?

**Write down your guesses!**

---

## Introduction

**Did you guess?** Let's see:

- **aller** = to go
- **prendre** = to take
- **faire** = to do / to make (here: to take a line)

In this lesson, you'll learn how to navigate Brussels using public transport. This is essential for your daily life as an expat!

**What you will learn today:**
- How to use the STIB network (metro, tram, bus)
- How to ask for and give directions
- The verbs "aller", "prendre" and "faire"
- Useful vocabulary for transport

**Belgian context:** Brussels has an excellent public transport network called STIB (in French) or MIVB (in Dutch). The MOBIB card is your key to all transport!

---

## French Pronunciation: Key Sounds for This Lesson

**Before we start, here are the key sounds you'll need:**

### The French R [ Å]

**Examples in this lesson:**
- **prendre** [p Å…ëÃÉd Å] - to take
- **m√©tro** [met Åo] - metro
- **gare** [ga Å] - station

### Nasal Sounds

**Examples:**
- **prendre** [p Å…ëÃÉd Å] - the "en" makes a nasal sound […ëÃÉ]
- **direction** [di Å…õksj…îÃÉ] - nasal […îÃÉ] at the end

**Quick Practice:** Say these words 3 times each:
- aller [ale]
- prendre [p Å…ëÃÉd Å]
- faire [f…õ Å]
- m√©tro [met Åo]

---

## Listening Comprehension: Getting Directions

**Listen to this conversation at a metro station:**

**Tom :** Excusez-moi, comment je fais pour aller √† la Gare Centrale ?

**Bruxelloise :** C'est facile ! Vous prenez le m√©tro ici, ligne 1, direction Stockel. Vous descendez √† la station Gare Centrale.

**Tom :** D'accord, merci ! Et c'est combien d'arr√™ts ?

**Bruxelloise :** C'est trois arr√™ts. √áa prend environ 5 minutes.

**Tom :** Super, merci beaucoup !

**Bruxelloise :** De rien, bonne route !

**Comprehension Questions:**

1. Where does Tom want to go?
2. Which metro line should he take?
3. How many stops is it?
4. How long does it take?

**Answers:**
1. To the Gare Centrale (Central Station)
2. Line 1, direction Stockel
3. Three stops
4. About 5 minutes

---

## Vocabulary: Transport in Brussels

**You just heard these words. Let's learn them:**

### Essential Transport Vocabulary

| Fran√ßais | IPA | English |
|----------|-----|---------|
| le m√©tro | [l…ô met Åo] | the metro |
| le tram | [l…ô t Åam] | the tram |
| le bus | [l…ô bys] | the bus |
| la station | [la stasj…îÃÉ] | the station |
| l'arr√™t | [la Å…õ] | the stop |
| la ligne | [la li…≤] | the line |
| la direction | [la di Å…õksj…îÃÉ] | the direction |
| la carte MOBIB | [la ka Åt mobib] | the MOBIB card |
| un ticket | [≈ìÃÉ tik…õ] | a ticket |
| la correspondance | [la k…î Å…õsp…îÃÉd…ëÃÉs] | the connection/transfer |

### Useful Expressions

| Fran√ßais | IPA | English |
|----------|-----|---------|
| Comment je fais pour aller √†... ? | [k…îm…ëÃÉ  í…ô f…õ pu Å ale a] | How do I get to...? |
| Je vais √†... | [ í…ô v…õ a] | I'm going to... |
| Je prends le m√©tro | [ í…ô p Å…ëÃÉ l…ô met Åo] | I take the metro |
| Je descends √†... | [ í…ô des…ëÃÉ a] | I get off at... |
| C'est combien d'arr√™ts ? | [s…õ k…îÃÉbj…õÃÉ da Å…õ] | How many stops is it? |
| O√π est la station... ? | [u …õ la stasj…îÃÉ] | Where is the... station? |
| C'est quelle direction ? | [s…õ k…õl di Å…õksj…îÃÉ] | Which direction is it? |

> **üó£Ô∏è Real Life French**
> 
> **"O√π c'est ?"** : Version tr√®s courante de "O√π est-ce ?" Vous entendrez souvent "La gare, o√π c'est ?" au lieu de "O√π est la gare ?".
> 
> **"Tu prends"** : En parlant vite, √ßa devient **"Tu prends"** [ty p Å…ëÃÉ]. Le "ds" final est muet.

---

## Grammar: The Verb "Aller" (To Go)

**Remember what you heard?**

- "Comment je fais pour **aller** √† la Gare Centrale ?"
- "Je **vais** au travail en m√©tro."

**What did you notice?** "Aller" is an irregular verb - it doesn't follow the -er pattern!

### Conjugation of "Aller"

| Pronom | Verbe "aller" | IPA | English |
|--------|---------------|-----|---------|
| Je | vais | [ í…ô v…õ] | I go |
| Tu | vas | [ty va] | You go (informal) |
| Il/Elle | va | [il/…õl va] | He/She goes |
| Nous | allons | [nu zal…îÃÉ] | We go |
| Vous | allez | [vu zale] | You go (formal/plural) |
| Ils/Elles | vont | [il/…õl v…îÃÉ] | They go |

**Examples you'll use daily:**
- **Je vais au travail.** = I go to work.
- **Tu vas o√π ?** = Where are you going?
- **On va au resto ?** = Shall we go to the restaurant?
- **Nous allons √† Bruges ce week-end.** = We're going to Bruges this weekend.

### Important: "Aller" + "√†" (contractions)

| √† + article | Contraction | Example |
|-------------|-------------|---------|
| √† + le | **au** | Je vais **au** bureau. |
| √† + la | √† la | Je vais **√† la** gare. |
| √† + l' | √† l' | Je vais **√† l'**a√©roport. |
| √† + les | **aux** | Je vais **aux** Pays-Bas. |

**‚ö†Ô∏è Watch out!**
- "Je vais **au** bureau" (not "√† le bureau")
- "Je vais **aux** toilettes" (not "√† les toilettes")

---

## Grammar: The Verb "Prendre" (To Take)

**Remember what you heard?**

- "Vous **prenez** le m√©tro ici."
- "Je **prends** le bus tous les jours."

### Conjugation of "Prendre"

| Pronom | Verbe "prendre" | IPA | English |
|--------|-----------------|-----|---------|
| Je | prends | [ í…ô p Å…ëÃÉ] | I take |
| Tu | prends | [ty p Å…ëÃÉ] | You take (informal) |
| Il/Elle | prend | [il/…õl p Å…ëÃÉ] | He/She takes |
| Nous | prenons | [nu p Å…ôn…îÃÉ] | We take |
| Vous | prenez | [vu p Å…ône] | You take (formal/plural) |
| Ils/Elles | prennent | [il/…õl p Å…õn] | They take |

**Examples you'll use daily:**
- **Je prends le m√©tro.** = I take the metro.
- **Tu prends quel bus ?** = Which bus do you take?
- **On prend un caf√© ?** = Shall we have a coffee?
- **Je prends la ligne 2.** = I take line 2.

**‚ö†Ô∏è Watch out!**
- "Je prends" and "Tu prends" sound the same [p Å…ëÃÉ]
- "Ils/Elles prennent" has a different sound [p Å…õn] - double "n"!

---

## Grammar: The Verb "Faire" (To Do/To Make)

**Remember what you heard?**

- "Comment je **fais** pour aller √†... ?"
- "Tu **fais** quelle ligne ?"

### Conjugation of "Faire"

| Pronom | Verbe "faire" | IPA | English |
|--------|---------------|-----|---------|
| Je | fais | [ í…ô f…õ] | I do/make |
| Tu | fais | [ty f…õ] | You do/make (informal) |
| Il/Elle | fait | [il/…õl f…õ] | He/She does/makes |
| Nous | faisons | [nu f…ôz…îÃÉ] | We do/make |
| Vous | faites | [vu f…õt] | You do/make (formal/plural) |
| Ils/Elles | font | [il/…õl f…îÃÉ] | They do/make |

**Examples you'll use daily:**
- **Comment je fais ?** = How do I do it?
- **Tu fais quoi ce soir ?** = What are you doing tonight?
- **Je fais du sport.** = I do sports.
- **On fait la ligne 6.** = We take line 6.

**üí° Note:** "Faire" is very versatile! It can mean "to do", "to make", or "to take" (a line/route).

---

## Grammar Exercises: Practice the Three Verbs

**Exercise 1: Complete with "aller"**

1. Je ______________ au travail en m√©tro.
2. Tu ______________ o√π ce soir ?
3. Elle ______________ √† la gare.
4. Nous ______________ √† Bruges demain.
5. Vous ______________ au restaurant ?
6. Ils ______________ aux Pays-Bas.

**Answers:**
1. vais
2. vas
3. va
4. allons
5. allez
6. vont

**Exercise 2: Complete with "prendre"**

1. Je ______________ le bus tous les jours.
2. Tu ______________ quel m√©tro ?
3. Il ______________ la ligne 1.
4. Nous ______________ un caf√© ?
5. Vous ______________ le tram ?
6. Elles ______________ le train.

**Answers:**
1. prends
2. prends
3. prend
4. prenons
5. prenez
6. prennent

**Exercise 3: Complete with "faire"**

1. Comment je ______________ pour aller √† Schuman ?
2. Tu ______________ quelle ligne ?
3. Elle ______________ du sport le matin.
4. Nous ______________ quoi ce week-end ?
5. Vous ______________ la correspondance √† Arts-Loi.
6. Ils ______________ du shopping.

**Answers:**
1. fais
2. fais
3. fait
4. faisons
5. faites
6. font

---

## Reading Comprehension: The STIB Network

**Read this text:**

Le r√©seau STIB √† Bruxelles comprend le m√©tro, le tram et le bus. Il y a 4 lignes de m√©tro : les lignes 1, 2, 5 et 6. Le m√©tro fonctionne de 5h30 √† minuit environ.

Pour utiliser les transports, vous avez besoin d'une carte MOBIB. Vous pouvez l'acheter dans les stations de m√©tro. Un ticket co√ªte environ 2,50‚Ç¨.

**Conseil pratique :** T√©l√©chargez l'application STIB pour voir les horaires en temps r√©el !

**Comprehension Questions:**

1. Combien de lignes de m√©tro y a-t-il √† Bruxelles ?
2. √Ä quelle heure commence le m√©tro ?
3. Qu'est-ce qu'il faut pour utiliser les transports ?
4. Combien co√ªte un ticket ?

**Answers:**
1. 4 lignes (1, 2, 5 et 6)
2. √Ä 5h30
3. Une carte MOBIB
4. Environ 2,50‚Ç¨

---

## Speaking Practice: Ask for Directions

**Model Dialogue:**

**You:** Excusez-moi, comment je fais pour aller √† [destination] ?

**Person:** Vous prenez le [m√©tro/tram/bus], ligne [num√©ro], direction [nom]. Vous descendez √† [station].

**You:** C'est combien d'arr√™ts ?

**Person:** C'est [nombre] arr√™ts.

**You:** Merci beaucoup !

**Your Turn:**

Practice asking how to get to these places:
- La Gare du Midi
- L'a√©roport de Bruxelles
- La Grand-Place
- Le Parlement europ√©en

---

## Writing Practice: Describe Your Commute

**Exercise: Write a short text (5-6 sentences) about how you get to work or school**

**Suggested structure:**
1. Where you live: "J'habite √†..."
2. Where you go: "Je vais √†..."
3. What transport you take: "Je prends..."
4. Which line/direction: "Je fais la ligne..."
5. Where you get off: "Je descends √†..."
6. How long it takes: "√áa prend... minutes"

**Example:**

J'habite √† Ixelles. Je vais au travail tous les jours. Je prends le tram 81 √† l'arr√™t Flagey. Je descends √† Montgomery, puis je prends le m√©tro ligne 1 direction Stockel. Je descends √† Schuman. √áa prend environ 25 minutes.

**Now write your own text!**

---

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

### Mistake 1: "Je vais √† le bureau" instead of "Je vais au bureau"

**Wrong:** "Je vais √† le bureau"  
**Correct:** "Je vais **au** bureau" ‚úÖ

**Why:** "√† + le" always contracts to "au". Same for "√† + les" = "aux".

### Mistake 2: "Je prend" instead of "Je prends"

**Wrong:** "Je prend le m√©tro"  
**Correct:** "Je **prends** le m√©tro" ‚úÖ

**Why:** The "s" is always there for "je" and "tu" even though it's silent.

### Mistake 3: Confusing "aller" and "partir"

**Wrong:** "Je vais de Bruxelles" (to say you're leaving Brussels)  
**Correct:** "Je **pars** de Bruxelles" ‚úÖ

**Why:** "Aller" = to go (to a destination). "Partir" = to leave (from a place).

### Mistake 4: "Je fais aller" instead of "Je vais"

**Wrong:** "Je fais aller au travail"  
**Correct:** "Je **vais** au travail" ‚úÖ

**Why:** "Faire" is not used with "aller". Just use "aller" directly.

---

## Survival Phrases: When You Don't Understand

**Essential phrases for transport:**

- **C'est loin ?** [s…õ lw…õÃÉ] = Is it far?
- **C'est pr√®s d'ici ?** [s…õ p Å…õ disi] = Is it near here?
- **√Ä pied, c'est combien de temps ?** [a pje s…õ k…îÃÉbj…õÃÉ d…ô t…ëÃÉ] = How long is it on foot?
- **Pouvez-vous r√©p√©ter, s'il vous pla√Æt ?** [puv vu  Åepete sil vu pl…õ] = Can you repeat, please?
- **Je suis perdu(e)** [ í…ô s…•i p…õ Ådy] = I'm lost
- **C'est quelle sortie ?** [s…õ k…õl s…î Åti] = Which exit is it?

---

## Belgian Culture: Transport in Brussels

**Did you know?**

- **The MOBIB card** is valid for metro, tram, bus, and even some trains in Brussels
- **Strike culture:** Belgium has frequent transport strikes. Check the news before traveling!
- **Validation:** Always validate your ticket when entering - inspectors do check!
- **Night transport:** There are "Noctis" night buses on weekends (Fri & Sat nights)

**Practical tip:** The STIB app shows real-time arrivals and can plan your route. Download it!

**Cultural comparison:**

In Belgium:
- Public transport is reliable and well-connected
- Many people use bikes combined with public transport
- The MOBIB card can be linked to your bank account

---

## Wrap-up: What You've Accomplished!

**Congratulations!** You've learned:

‚úÖ How to use the STIB network (metro, tram, bus)  
‚úÖ How to ask for and give directions  
‚úÖ The verb "aller" (to go) - irregular!  
‚úÖ The verb "prendre" (to take) - irregular!  
‚úÖ The verb "faire" (to do/make) - irregular!  
‚úÖ Transport vocabulary for daily life

**You're now ready to navigate Brussels!** üöá

---

## Self-Evaluation: Check What You Know!

**Can you...**
- [ ] Conjugate "aller" for all pronouns?
- [ ] Conjugate "prendre" for all pronouns?
- [ ] Conjugate "faire" for all pronouns?
- [ ] Ask "How do I get to...?" in French?

**How many can you do?**

- **5-6 checked:** Good progress! Review the parts you're not sure about.
- **Less than 5:** Don't worry! Go back and practice the verbs. Take your time!

---

## Extra Resources: Keep the Momentum Going!

**Want to practice more?**

- **Route Planner:** Open Google Maps or the STIB app and plan a trip from your home to "Gare du Midi" in French.
- **Station Name:** Look at a Brussels metro map and try to pronounce the names of 3 stations near the center.
- **Commute Narrator:** Narrate your next trip (even walking to the kitchen!): "Je marche... Je tourne √† gauche...".
- **Ticket Machine:** If you are in Belgium, change the language on the ticket machine to French just to see the options.

---

*Bonne continuation dans votre apprentissage du fran√ßais en Belgique !*
*Good luck with your French learning in Belgium!*

# Le√ßon 13 : Faire les courses √† Delhaize

**Niveau** : A1.1  
**Dur√©e estim√©e** : 2-3 heures  
**Objectifs** : Apprendre √† faire ses courses, utiliser les articles (un/une/le/la/les/du/de la) et la n√©gation (ne...pas)

---

## Let's Start! Shopping in Belgium

### Discovery Activity: At the Supermarket

**Here's a real situation you'll face:**

You're at Delhaize (a popular Belgian supermarket) and you hear people shopping:

**"Je prends du pain, de la confiture et des ≈ìufs. Je n'ai pas de lait, il faut en acheter."**

**Your challenge:** Look at these words and try to understand:

- **du pain** - What kind of word is "du"?

- **des ≈ìufs** - And "des"?

**Write down your guesses!**

---

## Introduction

**Did you guess?** Let's see:

- **du, de la, des** = some (partitive articles)
- **ne...pas** = not (negation)

In this lesson, you'll learn how to shop in Belgium and express what you have or don't have. Essential for daily life!

**What you will learn today:**
- Articles: un/une, le/la/les, du/de la/des
- How to say you don't have something (negation)
- Shopping vocabulary
- How to ask for things at the store

**Belgian context:** Delhaize, Colruyt, Carrefour, and Lidl are the main supermarkets. You'll also find small "night shops" (√©piceries de nuit) open late!

---

## French Pronunciation: Key Sounds for This Lesson

**Before we start, here are the key sounds you'll need:**

### Nasal Sounds

**Examples:**
- **pain** [p…õÃÉ] - bread (nasal "in")
- **viande** [vj…ëÃÉd] - meat (nasal "an")
- **confiture** [k…îÃÉfity Å] - jam (nasal "on")

### The Sound [√∏] in "des ≈ìufs"

- **≈ìufs** [√∏] - eggs (like "eu" in French)

**Quick Practice:** Say these words 3 times each:
- pain [p…õÃÉ]
- lait [l…õ]
- ≈ìufs [√∏]
- l√©gumes [legym]

---

## Listening Comprehension: At the Supermarket

**Listen to this conversation at Delhaize:**

**Vendeur :** Bonjour ! Vous d√©sirez ?

**Marie :** Bonjour ! Je voudrais du pain, s'il vous pla√Æt.

**Vendeur :** Voil√†. Autre chose ?

**Marie :** Oui, je prends aussi de la confiture et des ≈ìufs.

**Vendeur :** Parfait. C'est tout ?

**Marie :** Euh... vous avez du fromage belge ?

**Vendeur :** Oui, nous avons du Herve et du Chimay.

**Marie :** Je prends du Herve, s'il vous pla√Æt. Je n'ai pas besoin de beurre, j'en ai √† la maison.

**Vendeur :** Tr√®s bien. √áa fait 12 euros 50.

**Comprehension Questions:**

1. What does Marie want first?

3. What Belgian cheeses are available?

**Answers:**

---

## Vocabulary: Shopping

**You just heard these words. Let's learn them:**

### Food Vocabulary

| Fran√ßais | IPA | English |
|----------|-----|---------|
| le pain | [l…ô p…õÃÉ] | bread |
| le lait | [l…ô l…õ] | milk |
| le fromage | [l…ô f Å…îma í] | cheese |
| le beurre | [l…ô b≈ì Å] | butter |
| la confiture | [la k…îÃÉfity Å] | jam |
| la viande | [la vj…ëÃÉd] | meat |
| le poulet | [l…ô pul…õ] | chicken |
| le poisson | [l…ô pwas…îÃÉ] | fish |
| les ≈ìufs | [lez √∏] | eggs |
| les l√©gumes | [le legym] | vegetables |
| les fruits | [le f Å…•i] | fruits |
| l'eau | [lo] | water |

### Shopping Expressions

| Fran√ßais | IPA | English |
|----------|-----|---------|
| Je voudrais... | [ í…ô vud Å…õ] | I would like... |
| Je prends... | [ í…ô p Å…ëÃÉ] | I'll take... |
| Vous avez... ? | [vu zave] | Do you have...? |
| C'est combien ? | [s…õ k…îÃÉbj…õÃÉ] | How much is it? |
| Autre chose ? | [ot Å  Éoz] | Anything else? |
| C'est tout | [s…õ tu] | That's all |
| √áa fait... euros | [sa f…õ... √∏ Åo] | That comes to... euros |

> **üó£Ô∏è Real Life French**
> 
> **"Vous d√©sirez ?"** : C'est la fa√ßon polie de demander "Qu'est-ce que vous voulez ?". Tr√®s courant dans les magasins belges.
> 
> **"J'en prends"** : "En" remplace "de + quelque chose". "Du fromage ? J'en prends !" = "I'll take some!"

---

## Grammar: The Articles (Un/Une, Le/La/Les, Du/De la/Des)

**Remember what you heard?**

- "Je voudrais **du** pain"
- "Je prends **de la** confiture et **des** ≈ìufs"
- "Vous avez **du** fromage ?"

**What did you notice?** French has different articles depending on what you're expressing!

### The Three Types of Articles

| Type | Masculine | Feminine | Plural | When to use |
|:-----|:----------|:---------|:-------|:------------|
| **Indefinite** | **un** | **une** | **des** | A/an, some (countable) |
| **Definite** | **le** | **la** | **les** | The (specific) |
| **Partitive** | **du** | **de la** | **des** | Some (uncountable) |

### When to Use Each Article

**1. Indefinite (un/une/des) - "a/an, some" for countable items:**
- **Un** pain = A bread / One bread
- **Une** pomme = An apple
- **Des** ≈ìufs = Some eggs

**2. Definite (le/la/les) - "the" for specific items:**
- **Le** pain sur la table = The bread on the table
- **La** confiture de ma m√®re = My mother's jam
- **Les** ≈ìufs sont frais = The eggs are fresh

**3. Partitive (du/de la/des) - "some" for uncountable items:**
- Je veux **du** pain = I want (some) bread
- Je prends **de la** confiture = I'll take (some) jam
- J'ach√®te **des** l√©gumes = I buy (some) vegetables

### Summary Table with Examples

| Article | Example | Translation |
|:--------|:--------|:------------|
| **un** | Je veux **un** croissant | I want a croissant |
| **une** | Je prends **une** baguette | I'll take a baguette |
| **des** | J'ach√®te **des** pommes | I buy (some) apples |
| **le** | J'aime **le** chocolat belge | I like Belgian chocolate |
| **la** | **La** bi√®re est froide | The beer is cold |
| **les** | **Les** frites sont belges | Fries are Belgian |
| **du** | Je veux **du** fromage | I want (some) cheese |
| **de la** | Je prends **de la** confiture | I'll take (some) jam |

**üí° Memory trick:** 
- "Du" = de + le (masculine uncountable)
- "De la" = feminine uncountable
- "Des" = de + les (plural)

---

## Grammar: The Negation (Ne...Pas)

**Remember what you heard?**

- "Je **n'**ai **pas** de lait"
- "Je **n'**ai **pas** besoin de beurre"

**What did you notice?** Negation in French uses **two words**: "ne" and "pas"!

### How to Form Negation

**Structure:** Subject + **ne** + verb + **pas**

| Affirmative | Negative |
|:------------|:---------|
| J'ai du lait | Je **n'**ai **pas** de lait |
| Je prends du pain | Je **ne** prends **pas** de pain |
| Tu veux du caf√© | Tu **ne** veux **pas** de caf√© |
| Il mange du fromage | Il **ne** mange **pas** de fromage |

### Important Rule: "du/de la/des" ‚Üí "de" in Negation!

**Affirmative:** J'ai **du** lait, **de la** confiture, **des** ≈ìufs  
**Negative:** Je n'ai pas **de** lait, **de** confiture, **d'**≈ìufs

| Affirmative | Negative |
|:------------|:---------|
| J'ai **du** pain | Je n'ai pas **de** pain |
| J'ai **de la** viande | Je n'ai pas **de** viande |
| J'ai **des** ≈ìufs | Je n'ai pas **d'**≈ìufs |
| J'ai **un** chat | Je n'ai pas **de** chat |
| J'ai **une** voiture | Je n'ai pas **de** voiture |

**‚ö†Ô∏è Exception:** With "√™tre", the article doesn't change!
- C'est **un** bon fromage ‚Üí Ce **n'**est **pas un** bon fromage
- C'est **du** chocolat ‚Üí Ce **n'**est **pas du** chocolat

> **üó£Ô∏è Real Life French**
> 
> **Dropping "ne":** In spoken French, the "ne" often disappears! You'll hear:
> - "J'ai **pas** de lait" instead of "Je **n'**ai pas de lait"
> - "C'est **pas** cher" instead of "Ce **n'**est pas cher"
> 
> **For now, learn with "ne"** - it's correct and important for writing!

---

## Grammar Exercises: Practice Articles and Negation

**Exercise 1: Choose the correct article (un/une/du/de la/des)**

1. Je voudrais ______________ pain.
2. J'ach√®te ______________ pommes.
3. Tu veux ______________ caf√© ?
4. Je prends ______________ croissant.
5. Elle mange ______________ confiture.
6. Nous achetons ______________ l√©gumes.

**Answers:**
1. du pain
2. des pommes
3. du caf√©
4. un croissant
5. de la confiture
6. des l√©gumes

**Exercise 2: Transform to negative**

1. J'ai du lait. ‚Üí Je ______________.
2. Tu as des ≈ìufs. ‚Üí Tu ______________.
3. Elle prend de la viande. ‚Üí Elle ______________.
4. Nous avons un chien. ‚Üí Nous ______________.
5. Ils mangent du fromage. ‚Üí Ils ______________.

**Answers:**
1. Je n'ai pas de lait.
2. Tu n'as pas d'≈ìufs.
3. Elle ne prend pas de viande.
4. Nous n'avons pas de chien.
5. Ils ne mangent pas de fromage.

**Exercise 3: Complete the shopping list**

Write what you need and don't need:

J'ai besoin de... (I need...)
- ______________ (bread)
- ______________ (eggs)
- ______________ (cheese)

Je n'ai pas besoin de... (I don't need...)
- ______________ (milk)
- ______________ (butter)
- ______________ (meat)

**Answers:**
J'ai besoin de: du pain, des ≈ìufs, du fromage
Je n'ai pas besoin de: lait, beurre, viande

---

## Reading Comprehension: Belgian Supermarkets

**Read this text:**

En Belgique, il y a plusieurs supermarch√©s. Delhaize est tr√®s populaire - c'est une cha√Æne belge ! Colruyt est moins cher mais un peu plus loin du centre-ville. Carrefour et Lidl sont aussi tr√®s courants.

Pour les courses de derni√®re minute, il y a les "night shops" (√©piceries de nuit). Ils sont ouverts tard le soir, mais les prix sont plus √©lev√©s.

**Conseil pratique :** N'oubliez pas vos sacs r√©utilisables ! En Belgique, les sacs plastiques sont payants.

**Comprehension Questions:**

1. Quel supermarch√© est belge ?
2. Quel supermarch√© est moins cher ?
3. Pourquoi les night shops sont pratiques ?
4. Qu'est-ce qu'il ne faut pas oublier ?

**Answers:**
1. Delhaize
2. Colruyt
3. Ils sont ouverts tard le soir
4. Les sacs r√©utilisables

---

## Speaking Practice: At the Store

**Model Dialogue:**

**Vendeur:** Bonjour ! Vous d√©sirez ?

**You:** Bonjour ! Je voudrais [item], s'il vous pla√Æt.

**Vendeur:** Voil√†. Autre chose ?

**You:** Oui, je prends aussi [item] et [item].

**Vendeur:** C'est tout ?

**You:** Oui, c'est tout. / Non, vous avez [item] ?

**Vendeur:** √áa fait [price] euros.

**You:** Voil√†. Merci, bonne journ√©e !

**Your Turn:**

Practice ordering:
- du pain et du beurre
- des ≈ìufs et du lait
- de la confiture et du fromage

---

## Writing Practice: Your Shopping List

**Exercise: Write a shopping list in French (8-10 items)**

**Structure:**
1. List what you need: "J'ai besoin de..."
2. List what you don't need: "Je n'ai pas besoin de..."

**Example:**

**Ma liste de courses :**

J'ai besoin de :
- du pain
- du lait
- des ≈ìufs
- de la confiture
- des l√©gumes (tomates, carottes)
- du fromage belge

Je n'ai pas besoin de :
- beurre (j'en ai √† la maison)
- viande (je suis v√©g√©tarien)

**Now write your own list!**

---

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

### Mistake 1: Using "du/de la/des" with negation

**Wrong:** "Je n'ai pas du lait"  
**Correct:** "Je n'ai pas **de** lait" ‚úÖ

**Why:** After negation, all partitive articles become just "de" (or "d'" before vowel).

### Mistake 2: Forgetting "ne" in negation

**Wrong:** "J'ai pas de pain" (too informal for writing)  
**Correct:** "Je **n'**ai pas de pain" ‚úÖ

**Why:** Written French needs both "ne" and "pas". Spoken French often drops "ne", but learn the full form first!

### Mistake 3: Using "un/une" with uncountable nouns

**Wrong:** "Je veux une lait" or "Je prends un beurre"  
**Correct:** "Je veux **du** lait" or "Je prends **du** beurre" ‚úÖ

**Why:** Milk and butter are uncountable - use "du" (partitive), not "un/une" (indefinite).

### Mistake 4: Forgetting to change "d'" before vowels

**Wrong:** "Je n'ai pas de ≈ìufs"  
**Correct:** "Je n'ai pas **d'**≈ìufs" ‚úÖ

**Why:** "De" becomes "d'" before a vowel sound.

---

## Survival Phrases: At the Store

**Essential phrases:**

- **C'est combien ?** [s…õ k…îÃÉbj…õÃÉ] = How much is it?
- **C'est trop cher** [s…õ t Åo  É…õ Å] = It's too expensive
- **Je cherche...** [ í…ô  É…õ Å É] = I'm looking for...
- **O√π sont les...?** [u s…îÃÉ le] = Where are the...?
- **Vous acceptez la carte ?** [vu zaks…õpte la ka Åt] = Do you accept cards?
- **Je peux payer en esp√®ces ?** [ í…ô p√∏ peje …ëÃÉn …õsp…õs] = Can I pay cash?

---

## Belgian Culture: Shopping in Belgium

**Did you know?**

- **Sunday shopping:** Most supermarkets are closed on Sundays! Plan ahead.
- **Reusable bags:** Plastic bags cost money. Bring your own!
- **Belgian specialties:** Look for speculoos, sirop de Li√®ge, and Belgian cheeses
- **Night shops:** Open late but more expensive. Good for emergencies!

**Practical tip:** Colruyt is the cheapest but you need to bag your own groceries. Delhaize is more expensive but has great Belgian products!

---

## Wrap-up: What You've Accomplished!

**Congratulations!** You've learned:

‚úÖ Articles: un/une (indefinite), le/la/les (definite), du/de la/des (partitive)  
‚úÖ Negation: ne...pas  
‚úÖ The rule: du/de la/des ‚Üí de in negation  
‚úÖ Shopping vocabulary  
‚úÖ How to ask for things at the store

**You're now ready to shop in Belgium!** üõí

---

## Self-Evaluation: Check What You Know!

**Can you...**
- [ ] Use "un/une" correctly?
- [ ] Use "le/la/les" correctly?
- [ ] Use "du/de la/des" correctly?
- [ ] Form negative sentences with "ne...pas"?
- [ ] Change articles in negative sentences (du ‚Üí de)?
- [ ] Order items at a store?
- [ ] Write a shopping list in French?

**How many can you do?**
- **7 checked:** Excellent! You've mastered this lesson! üéâ
- **5-6 checked:** Good progress! Review the articles.
- **Less than 5:** Don't worry! Practice the article exercises again.

---

## Extra Resources: Keep the Momentum Going!

**Want to practice more?**

- Write your real shopping list in French every week
- Practice at the store: try ordering in French!
- Watch French cooking videos (good for food vocabulary)
- Visit a Belgian market and practice!

---

*Good luck with your French learning in Belgium!*

---

## Extra Resources: Keep the Momentum Going!

**Want to practice more?**

- **Pantry Raid:** Open your fridge and list 5 items in French ("Il y a du lait", "Il n'y a pas de beurre").
- **Real Shopping:** Next time you are at the store, try to think "Je veux du..." for every item you pick up.
- **Recipe Hunt:** Find a simple recipe (e.g., "P√¢te √† cr√™pes") in French online and write down the ingredients list using partitive articles ("Il faut de la farine, du lait...").
- **Price Check:** Look at a flyer from a Belgian supermarkets (Colruyt/Delhaize) and read the prices aloud.

---

*Bonne continuation dans votre apprentissage du fran√ßais en Belgique !*
*Good luck with your French learning in Belgium!*

# Le√ßon 14 : √Ä la commune - Les d√©marches administratives

**Niveau** : A1.1  
**Dur√©e estim√©e** : 2-3 heures  
**Objectifs** : Apprendre √† poser des questions, comprendre les d√©marches administratives belges

---

## Let's Start! At the Town Hall

### Discovery Activity: Questions at the Commune

**Here's a real situation you'll face:**

You just arrived in Belgium and you need to register at the commune (town hall). You hear other expats asking:

**"O√π est le guichet pour les √©trangers ?"**  
**"Qu'est-ce qu'il faut comme documents ?"**  
**"Quand est-ce que je recevrai ma carte d'identit√© ?"**

**Your challenge:** Look at these question words and try to guess what they mean:

- **O√π** - What do you think this means?
- **Qu'est-ce que** - What about this?
- **Quand** - And this one?

**Write down your guesses!**

---

## Introduction

**Did you guess?** Let's see:

- **O√π** = Where
- **Qu'est-ce que** = What
- **Quand** = When

In this lesson, you'll learn how to ask questions in French - essential for navigating Belgian administration!

**What you will learn today:**
- Question words: qui, quoi, o√π, quand, comment, pourquoi
- How to form questions in French
- Vocabulary for administrative procedures
- How to survive at the commune!

**Belgian context:** In Belgium, you must register at the commune within 8 days of moving. The commune is your local town hall where you get your ID card, driving license, and other documents.

---

## French Pronunciation: Key Sounds for This Lesson

**Before we start, here are the key sounds you'll need:**

### The Sound [wa] in "quoi"

**Examples:**
- **quoi** [kwa] - what
- **pourquoi** [pu Åkwa] - why

### The Nasal Sound […ëÃÉ] in "quand"

**Examples:**
- **quand** [k…ëÃÉ] - when
- **comment** [k…îm…ëÃÉ] - how

**Quick Practice:** Say these words 3 times each:
- o√π [u]
- quoi [kwa]
- quand [k…ëÃÉ]
- comment [k…îm…ëÃÉ]

---

## Listening Comprehension: At the Commune

**Listen to this conversation at the commune:**

**Tom :** Bonjour, excusez-moi, **o√π** est le guichet pour les √©trangers ?

**Employ√©e :** Bonjour ! C'est au premier √©tage, guichet 3.

**Tom :** Merci. **Qu'est-ce qu'**il faut comme documents ?

**Employ√©e :** Vous avez besoin de votre passeport, une preuve d'adresse, et deux photos d'identit√©.

**Tom :** D'accord. **Combien** de temps √ßa prend ?

**Employ√©e :** Environ 30 minutes. Mais aujourd'hui il y a beaucoup de monde.

**Tom :** Et **quand** est-ce que je recevrai ma carte d'identit√© ?

**Employ√©e :** Dans environ 3 semaines. On vous enverra un courrier.

**Tom :** **Comment** je fais pour prendre rendez-vous la prochaine fois ?

**Employ√©e :** Vous pouvez r√©server en ligne sur le site de la commune.

**Tom :** Parfait, merci beaucoup !

**Comprehension Questions:**

1. Where is the counter for foreigners?
2. What documents does Tom need?
3. How long does the procedure take?
4. When will Tom receive his ID card?

**Answers:**
1. On the first floor, counter 3
2. Passport, proof of address, and two ID photos
3. About 30 minutes
4. In about 3 weeks

---

## Vocabulary: At the Commune

**You just heard these words. Let's learn them:**

### Administrative Vocabulary

| Fran√ßais | IPA | English |
|----------|-----|---------|
| la commune | [la k…îmyn] | town hall |
| le guichet | [l…ô gi É…õ] | counter/window |
| un rendez-vous | [≈ìÃÉ  Å…ëÃÉdevu] | an appointment |
| la carte d'identit√© | [la ka Åt did…ëÃÉtite] | ID card |
| le passeport | [l…ô pasp…î Å] | passport |
| une preuve d'adresse | [yn p Å≈ìv dad Å…õs] | proof of address |
| une photo d'identit√© | [yn foto did…ëÃÉtite] | ID photo |
| le formulaire | [l…ô f…î Åmyl…õ Å] | form |
| la signature | [la si…≤aty Å] | signature |
| le permis de s√©jour | [l…ô p…õ Åmi d…ô se íu Å] | residence permit |

### Useful Expressions

| Fran√ßais | IPA | English |
|----------|-----|---------|
| J'ai besoin de... | [ íe b…ôzw…õÃÉ d…ô] | I need... |
| Qu'est-ce qu'il faut ? | [k…õs kil fo] | What is needed? |
| Combien de temps √ßa prend ? | [k…îÃÉbj…õÃÉ d…ô t…ëÃÉ sa p Å…ëÃÉ] | How long does it take? |
| Je voudrais prendre rendez-vous | [ í…ô vud Å…õ p Å…ëÃÉd Å  Å…ëÃÉdevu] | I would like to make an appointment |
| C'est pour... | [s…õ pu Å] | It's for... |
| Je viens pour... | [ í…ô vj…õÃÉ pu Å] | I'm here for... |

> **üó£Ô∏è Real Life French**
> 
> **"C'est o√π ?"** : Version courante de "O√π est-ce ?". "Le guichet, c'est o√π ?" = "Where's the counter?"
> 
> **"Il faut"** : Expression tr√®s utile ! "Il faut un passeport" = "You need a passport" / "A passport is needed"

---

## Grammar: Question Words

**Remember what you heard?**

- "**O√π** est le guichet ?"
- "**Qu'est-ce qu'**il faut ?"
- "**Quand** est-ce que je recevrai ma carte ?"
- "**Comment** je fais ?"

**What did you notice?** French uses different question words for different types of questions!

### The Essential Question Words

| Fran√ßais | IPA | English | Example |
|:---------|:----|:--------|:--------|
| **Qui** | [ki] | Who | **Qui** parle fran√ßais ? (Who speaks French?) |
| **Quoi** / **Que** | [kwa] / [k…ô] | What | **Quoi** ? / C'est **quoi** ? (What?) |
| **O√π** | [u] | Where | **O√π** est la gare ? (Where is the station?) |
| **Quand** | [k…ëÃÉ] | When | **Quand** ouvre la commune ? (When does the town hall open?) |
| **Comment** | [k…îm…ëÃÉ] | How | **Comment** √ßa va ? (How are you?) |
| **Pourquoi** | [pu Åkwa] | Why | **Pourquoi** tu apprends le fran√ßais ? (Why are you learning French?) |
| **Combien** | [k…îÃÉbj…õÃÉ] | How much/many | **Combien** √ßa co√ªte ? (How much does it cost?) |

### Three Ways to Ask Questions

**1. Intonation (informal) - Just raise your voice at the end:**
- Tu habites **o√π** ? ‚Üó
- C'est **quoi** ? ‚Üó
- Tu viens **quand** ? ‚Üó

**2. "Est-ce que" (standard) - Add "est-ce que" at the beginning:**
- **O√π est-ce que** tu habites ?
- **Qu'est-ce que** c'est ?
- **Quand est-ce que** tu viens ?

**3. Inversion (formal) - Switch the subject and verb:**
- **O√π** habites-**tu** ?
- **Qu'**est-**ce** ?
- **Quand** viens-**tu** ?

**üí° For beginners:** Start with #1 (intonation) and #2 (est-ce que). They're the easiest!

### "Qu'est-ce que" - The Most Useful Question Formula

**Structure:** Qu'est-ce que + subject + verb?

| Question | Translation |
|:---------|:------------|
| **Qu'est-ce que** tu fais ? | What are you doing? |
| **Qu'est-ce que** c'est ? | What is it? |
| **Qu'est-ce qu'**il faut ? | What is needed? |
| **Qu'est-ce que** tu veux ? | What do you want? |

**Note:** Before a vowel, "que" becomes "qu'"
- Qu'est-ce qu'**i**l faut ? (not "que il")

### "Est-ce que" - Turning Statements into Questions

**Structure:** Est-ce que + statement?

| Statement | Question |
|:----------|:---------|
| Tu parles fran√ßais. | **Est-ce que** tu parles fran√ßais ? |
| C'est ouvert. | **Est-ce que** c'est ouvert ? |
| Vous avez le formulaire. | **Est-ce que** vous avez le formulaire ? |

---

## Grammar Exercises: Practice Questions

**Exercise 1: Choose the correct question word**

1. ______________ est la commune ? (Where)
2. ______________ ouvre la commune ? (When)
3. ______________ √ßa co√ªte ? (How much)
4. ______________ je fais pour m'inscrire ? (How)
5. ______________ parle fran√ßais ici ? (Who)
6. ______________ tu as besoin ? (What)

**Answers:**
1. O√π
2. Quand
3. Combien
4. Comment
5. Qui
6. De quoi (Qu'est-ce que)

**Exercise 2: Transform to questions using "est-ce que"**

1. Tu habites √† Bruxelles. ‚Üí _______________________________?
2. C'est ouvert le samedi. ‚Üí _______________________________?
3. Vous avez un rendez-vous. ‚Üí _______________________________?
4. Il faut un passeport. ‚Üí _______________________________?

**Answers:**
1. Est-ce que tu habites √† Bruxelles ?
2. Est-ce que c'est ouvert le samedi ?
3. Est-ce que vous avez un rendez-vous ?
4. Est-ce qu'il faut un passeport ?

**Exercise 3: Create questions for these answers**

1. _______________? ‚Üí La commune est rue de la Loi.
2. _______________? ‚Üí Le guichet ouvre √† 9 heures.
3. _______________? ‚Üí √áa co√ªte 25 euros.
4. _______________? ‚Üí Il faut un passeport et deux photos.

**Answers:**
1. O√π est la commune ?
2. Quand ouvre le guichet ? / √Ä quelle heure ouvre le guichet ?
3. Combien √ßa co√ªte ?
4. Qu'est-ce qu'il faut ?

---

## Reading Comprehension: Belgian Administration

**Read this text:**

En Belgique, quand vous arrivez, vous devez vous inscrire √† la commune dans les 8 jours. C'est obligatoire !

**Documents n√©cessaires :**
- Passeport valide
- Preuve d'adresse (contrat de bail ou attestation du propri√©taire)
- 2 photos d'identit√©

Apr√®s l'inscription, un agent de police viendra v√©rifier votre adresse. Ensuite, vous recevrez votre carte d'identit√© par la poste, environ 3 semaines plus tard.

**Conseil pratique :** Prenez rendez-vous en ligne pour √©viter l'attente !

**Comprehension Questions:**

1. Dans combien de jours faut-il s'inscrire ?
2. Qu'est-ce qu'une preuve d'adresse ?
3. Qui viendra v√©rifier votre adresse ?
4. Comment recevoir la carte d'identit√© plus vite ?

**Answers:**
1. Dans 8 jours
2. Un contrat de bail ou une attestation du propri√©taire
3. Un agent de police
4. Prendre rendez-vous en ligne

---

## Speaking Practice: At the Commune

**Model Dialogue:**

**You:** Bonjour, je viens pour [reason].

**Employ√©:** Bonjour, vous avez pris rendez-vous ?

**You:** Oui / Non, est-ce que c'est possible sans rendez-vous ?

**Employ√©:** Oui, mais il y a de l'attente. Qu'est-ce qu'il vous faut ?

**You:** Je voudrais [service]. Qu'est-ce qu'il faut comme documents ?

**Employ√©:** Il faut [documents].

**You:** D'accord. Combien de temps √ßa prend ?

**Employ√©:** Environ [time].

**Your Turn:**

Practice these scenarios:
- Inscription √† la commune (registration)
- Demande de carte d'identit√© (ID card request)
- Changement d'adresse (address change)

---

## Writing Practice: Prepare for Your Commune Visit

## Writing Practice: Your Commune Script

**Task:** Prepare your exact script for going to the commune. Write down exactly what you will say to the employee.

**Scenario:** You need to register (s'inscrire) and you want to know what documents to bring.

**Complete your script:**

1.  **Greeting:** (Don't forget this!) _______________________________
2.  **State your specific goal:** (Je voudrais...) _______________________________
3.  **Ask what documents are needed:** (Qu'est-ce que...) _______________________________
4.  **Ask about the timing:** (Combien de temps...) _______________________________
5.  **Closing:** (Merci, au revoir) _______________________________

**Model Script:**
> "Bonjour Madame. Je voudrais m'inscrire √† la commune. Qu'est-ce qu'il faut comme documents ? Et combien de temps √ßa prend pour recevoir la carte ? Merci, au revoir."

**Now write YOUR script:**
_________________________________________________________________________
_________________________________________________________________________

---

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

### Mistake 1: "O√π est-ce que est..." instead of "O√π est..."

**Wrong:** "O√π est-ce que **est** la gare ?"  
**Correct:** "**O√π est** la gare ?" or "O√π **est-ce que** la gare **se trouve** ?" ‚úÖ

**Why:** "O√π" + "est" is already a question. Don't add "est-ce que" before another "est".

### Mistake 2: Forgetting "que" in "Qu'est-ce que"

**Wrong:** "Qu'est-ce tu fais ?"  
**Correct:** "**Qu'est-ce que** tu fais ?" ‚úÖ

**Why:** The full formula is "Qu'est-ce que" + subject + verb.

### Mistake 3: Using "quoi" at the beginning of formal questions

**Wrong:** "Quoi tu fais ?"  
**Correct:** "**Qu'est-ce que** tu fais ?" or "Tu fais **quoi** ?" ‚úÖ

**Why:** "Quoi" usually goes at the end (informal) or use "Qu'est-ce que" at the beginning.

### Mistake 4: "Quand tu viens ?" without "est-ce que"

**Wrong:** "Quand tu viens ?" (incomplete)  
**Correct:** "**Quand est-ce que** tu viens ?" or "Tu viens **quand** ?" ‚úÖ

**Why:** Question word + subject + verb needs "est-ce que" in the middle, or put the question word at the end.

---

## Survival Phrases: At the Commune

**Essential phrases:**

- **Je ne comprends pas** [ í…ô n…ô k…îÃÉp Å…ëÃÉ pa] = I don't understand
- **Pouvez-vous r√©p√©ter ?** [puve vu  Åepete] = Can you repeat?
- **Pouvez-vous parler plus lentement ?** [puve vu pa Åle ply l…ëÃÉtm…ëÃÉ] = Can you speak more slowly?
- **C'est urgent** [s…õt y Å í…ëÃÉ] = It's urgent
- **J'ai rendez-vous** [ íe  Å…ëÃÉdevu] = I have an appointment
- **Je n'ai pas de rendez-vous** [ í…ô ne pa d…ô  Å…ëÃÉdevu] = I don't have an appointment
- **O√π dois-je signer ?** [u dwa  í…ô si…≤e] = Where should I sign?

---

## Belgian Culture: The Commune System

**Did you know?**

- **19 communes:** Brussels has 19 different communes, each with its own town hall!
- **8-day rule:** You must register within 8 days of moving to Belgium
- **Police check:** After registration, a police officer will visit your home to verify your address
- **Online services:** Many communes now offer online appointments - use them!

**Practical tip:** Bring ALL your documents the first time. Missing one document = coming back another day!

**Common documents needed:**
- Valid passport
- Proof of address (rental contract)
- 2 ID photos (35mm x 45mm)
- Work contract or proof of income (sometimes)

---

## Wrap-up: What You've Accomplished!

**Congratulations!** You've learned:

‚úÖ Question words: qui, quoi, o√π, quand, comment, pourquoi, combien  
‚úÖ Three ways to ask questions in French  
‚úÖ "Est-ce que" and "Qu'est-ce que" formulas  
‚úÖ Administrative vocabulary  
‚úÖ How to survive at the commune!

**You're now ready to navigate Belgian administration!** üèõÔ∏è

---

## Self-Evaluation: Check What You Know!

**Can you...**
- [ ] Use all the question words correctly?
- [ ] Form questions with "est-ce que"?
- [ ] Use "Qu'est-ce que" to ask "what"?
- [ ] Ask where something is?
- [ ] Ask when something opens?
- [ ] Ask how to do something?

**How many can you do?**
- **7 checked:** Excellent! You've mastered this lesson! üéâ
- **5-6 checked:** Good progress! Review the question formulas.
- **Less than 5:** Don't worry! Practice the question exercises again.

---

## Extra Resources: Keep the Momentum Going!

**Want to practice more?**

- Visit your commune's website (in French) and find information

---

*Good luck with your French learning in Belgium!*

---

## Extra Resources: Keep the Momentum Going!
